story.text: (Adds details, prices)TORONTO Jan 3 (Reuters) - The Toronto Stock Exchange's main index shed more than 200 points on Wednesday, as investors bailed out of sinking resource and energy issues, dragging down the broader market. The S&P/TSX composite index .GSPTSE fell 201.47 points, or 1.6 percent, to 12,722.19 shortly after 2 p.m., extending a steep retreat that first hit the benchmark shortly after trading began. The energy and resource-heavy materials groups led the decline, falling 4 percent and 3.9 percent respectively The top net losers' list on Wednesday read like a "Who's Who" of the energy and mining industries, as investors soured on the shares on concerns over underlying commodity prices. Zinc giant Teck Cominco Ltd. (TCKb.TO) sank C$4.53, or 5.3 percent, to C$81.40. First Quantum Minerals (FM.TO) fell C$7.10, or 11.5 percent, C$54.40. Agnico-Eagle Mines Ltd. (AEM.TO) gave up C$3.96, or 8.1 percent, to C$45.19. Among energy names, Suncor Energy Inc. (SU.TO) dove C$4.15, or 4.6 percent, to C$86.87. Nexen Inc. NXY.TO was down C$2.79, or 4.3 percent, at C$61.82. The losses first hit the TSX this morning as concern mounted over oil sinking to below $60 a barrel due to warm weather in the United States, which ate into heating oil demand. Base metals prices, responsible for the declines in the materials group, also fell on Wednesday, led by copper which touched its lowest levels since April. ($1=$1.17 Canadian)
story.title: toronto stock index sags 200 pts on energy , metals
